p: The 2009 Influenza A (H1N1) pandemic posed one of the most serious global public health challenges in recent years [ 1]. With the ease and speed of global travel in the 21st century, the world is now a global village in terms of epidemic transmission [ 2]. The Influenza A (H1N1) virus can transmit from humans to humans by direct body contact or respiratory droplets. The infectious disease can spread widely as people carrying pathogens travel and commute between cities by multiple means of transport. Thus, intercity travel is important for the diffusion of viruses [ 3, 4, 5].
